awd_titl_txt: Female Gaze, Retinal Specializations, and the Evolution of Complex Male Courtship Displays in Habronattus Jumping Spiders
awd_abstract_narration:
Studies of complex animal visual displays (e.g., colors, patterns, movements) allow us to uncover how complexity can result from the coevolution of signals and the eyes that perceive them.  During courtship, the unusually colorful male Habronattus jumping spiders engage in elaborate dances that showcase movements, colors, and patterns to prospective mates. Although females react to these displays by changing where they face, we know almost nothing about where females look during courtship, or how male displays function to manipulate female gaze. To understand how these displays have evolved to capture and retain female visual attention, this research program will use newly available eye tracking technology and digital tools to examine interactions between male displays and female gaze in the Fiery Haired Jumping Spider, Habronattus pyrrithrix. The research team will then expand their work to 20 additional Habronattus species to understand broader patterns of display evolution. This research program will allow us to better understand how animals communicate through complex visual displays and how evolution shapes complex signals. In addition, the scientific team will use insights from their research to enrich educational collaborations with community partners. These partnerships include the development and implementation of curricula for regional public schools, as well as biomimicry-themed "superhero summer camps" and afterschool programming in collaboration with Assemble, a Pittsburgh-based non-profit organization which focuses on teaching inner-city youth about science by integrating art into science education.

One widespread feature of visual systems is distinct regionalization of visual competency across the visual field, including regions of heightened motion sensitivity, spatial acuity and/or color vision. Animals compensate for this regionalization with movements of the head or eyes that aim specialized retinal regions at areas of interest within the visual scene. These gaze movements determine what animals see when they interact with visual stimuli. However, despite the fundamental importance of gaze to animal vision, we know almost nothing about how animals use their gaze to evaluate communicatory displays. We know even less about how visual displays have evolved to effectively capture, retain or manipulate the gaze of signal receivers. This research will build upon current understandings of the coevolution of visual signals and visual systems by evaluating the evolutionary relevance of gaze-display dynamics for diversification of male courtship displays in Habronattus spiders. The research will employ gaze-tracking, video playbacks, and digital and physical manipulations of male displays to reveal basic properties of gaze-display interactions in the species Habronattus pyrrithrix. Leveraging insights derived from these in-depth studies, the research will use comparative approaches to test broader hypotheses regarding the evolution of gaze-display interactions across the genus Habronattus.

por.por_cntn:
Animals often perform wildly complex courtship displays, combining motion, pattern, color, sound/vibration, and chemical signals. Understanding the evolution of this complexity has been a central challenge for behavioral ecologists for the past several decades. Why doesn?t a simpler display suffice? One possible explanation is that courtship displays evolve to capture and retain attention, and that the fickleness of attentiveness has led to ever more complex strategies on the part of the displayer. In this research project, Morehouse and colleagues sought to test this idea using the elaborate courtship displays and associated female attentiveness of jumping spiders in the genus Habronattus.

 

Morehouse and colleagues made a number of key discoveries. First, they found that female attentiveness is critical to courtship outcomes. During courtship, females only pay attention to the displaying male ~21% of the time, whereas displaying males face females ~99% of the time. Males also appear unable or unwilling to move around the female to regain her attention, relying instead on their displays to recapture female interest. This suggests that male displays may have evolved based on their effectiveness at (re)capturing female attention.

 

In a follow-up study, these researchers found that the leg waving displays that males perform at the beginning of their courtship are highly effective at capturing female visual interest, outperforming other forms of male motion, especially when presented against complex and/or moving backgrounds. Males also respond specifically to environmental complexity by moving closer to their female audience, thereby making their waving displays more conspicuous from the female?s vantage point. This suggests that male waving displays may have evolved specifically to establish initial visual engagement on the part of the female. Morehouse and colleagues are following up on this possibility by investigating whether differences in environmental motion across habitats (e.g. wind-based foliage movement) have led to species differences in the motion characteristics of their waving displays.

 

Morehouse and colleagues, in collaboration with Elizabeth Jakob and her research team, then asked whether male courtship displays serve to retain female visual attention, particularly where females ?look? with the movable gaze of their principal eyes. Jumping spiders have unusual visual systems composed of eight eyes. Six of these eyes are called ?secondary? eyes, and provide a motion-sensitive, modest-resolution, monochromatic view of the world similar to our peripheral vision. An additional pair of eyes, called the ?principal eyes?, provide extraordinary resolution and color vision, but only for a very narrow forward-facing field of view, similar to our foveal vision. However, unlike our eyes, which can rotate in their sockets, jumping spiders change the direction of their principal eye gaze by moving their retinas around inside their heads via a set of retinal muscles. Using a custom-built ophthalmoscope, Morehouse, Jakob, and colleagues tracked where female retinas ?looked? when they viewed videos of courting males. Because these researchers were working with video playbacks, they were able to alter the male displays to manipulate male motions and color.

 

In the focal species Habronattus pyrrithrix, these researchers found that male display motions were essential in guiding where females looked, with display motions in different parts of the display timed to pass female visual attention from one area to the next. In addition, Morehouse, Jakob, and colleagues found that color was essential in retaining female attention once a display movement had drawn her interest. Females were more likely to lose interest in display elements that lacked color, moving to other elements in the display or elsewhere on the screen more rapidly when displays were presented in black-and-white.

 

These researchers then expanded this gaze-tracking working to the broader diversity of displays in the genus Habronattus. Across the genus, the same patterns held. Motion was essential in dictating where females looked, whereas color played a role in how long females spent looking at either single display elements and/or at the display in general. In addition, gaze patterns observed in some species suggested that females might be sequentially evaluating different elements of the display, an approach that may help females to simplify their assessment of the overwhelming complexity of the male display, while at the same time benefiting the male by increasing the length of time that a female attends to his display.

 

Taken together, these results provide clear evidence that male jumping spider courtship elements have evolved specifically to capture and retain female visual attention. Further, specific courtship elements, such as motion and color, appear to collaborate to extend the length of female visual interest, thereby providing a mechanistic explanation for the exuberant complexity of these displays.

 

Morehouse and colleagues extended these scientific insights into a suite of educational programming efforts, including summer camps, after-school programming, and exhibit activities in collaboration with non-profit educational institutions like Assemble Pittsburgh, the Cincinnati Museum Center?s STEM Girls Academy, the Carnegie Museum of Natural History, Phipps Conservatory, and visits to dozens of classrooms.
